claim: Create value for your target market with your marketing—so valuable they'd pay for it. Marketing must create value, not pollution.
rationale: Most marketing is interruption that creates negative externalities. Value-creating marketing builds goodwill, even for those who never buy.

claim: Market comes before product. Start with a crystal-clear target market and their specific problems.
rationale: A solution in search of a problem wastes spend. Narrow focus ('inch wide, mile deep') makes messaging specific and effective.

claim: Define target market across seven dimensions: location, demography, shared values, industry, desire, problem, trend.
rationale: Multiple dimensions increase resonance ('this is for me') while ensuring the niche is still large and growing.

claim: All buying is driven by seven commodities: Money/Wealth, Time/Convenience, Sex/Mating, Status/Fame/Approval, Safety/Peace of Mind, Leisure/Entertainment, Freedom.
rationale: Features matter less than the core human drives they satisfy. Convenience and time often dominate decisions.

claim: Decide if you are a painkiller or vitamin. Painkillers trigger urgency; vitamins do not.
rationale: Markets decide this, not you. Urgency and PMF are stronger when positioned as painkiller.

claim: Increase value by decreasing time, effort, risk, and negative side effects—prefer this over lowering price.
rationale: Price cuts are a race to the bottom. Reducing risk and friction raises perceived value sustainably.

claim: Price signals quality and status. Value-based pricing beats cost-plus; avoid the mediocre middle.
rationale: Too-low price signals low quality. Premium pricing can be a feature of positioning.

claim: Brochure websites with generic claims and weak CTAs fail to convert; without lead capture, 97% of visitors are lost.
rationale: Websites need a job and KPIs. Relevant content upgrades capture emails from visitors not ready to buy.

claim: Selling is the best way to build a brand. Brand enables premium pricing; goodwill comes from repeated positive experiences.
rationale: If customers won’t pay a premium, you don’t truly have a brand. Early focus should be sales and direct interaction.

claim: Flagship asset: a value-creating tool/content that lets prospects get a result in advance (Michelin Guide, DIY versions, diagnostic tools).
rationale: Shows rather than tells, demonstrates capability, turns invisible prospects visible, builds trust.

claim: Adopt a media-company mindset. Create content that pulls the right audience instead of pushing unwanted messages.
rationale: Building an audience/community creates natural demand; relevant interest beats raw traffic.

claim: The first 100 days are critical for retention; onboarding must create early wins and integration into workflow.
rationale: Buyers feel remorse and see effort; quick wins maintain momentum and reduce churn in subscriptions.

claim: LTV is the marketing metric that matters most; base LTV on profit, not revenue.
rationale: LTV informs acquisition/retention spend and moat size. Grow via price, upsell, frequency, reactivation.

claim: Break even or profit on the front end to unlock effectively unlimited marketing budget.
rationale: If first-transaction economics work, you can reinvest indefinitely; competitors constrained by CAC are disadvantaged.

claim: Relying on generalist marketing agencies for core functions produces safe, low-impact output; build core marketing in-house.
rationale: Agencies split attention and own the IP. Copy, content, infrastructure should be internal; specialists only for specific tasks.

claim: Test, measure, and improve each step of campaigns. Diagnose which of the five failure points is breaking and fix it.
rationale: Low conversion is normal; targeted fixes beat generic changes. Five points: ad click, opt-in, open, visit, buy.
